moves.1. e4 d5 2. exd5 Qxd5 3. Nc3 Qe5+: I read once an article called "the Qa5 phallacy". So I play this "my" way.
moves.4. Be2 c6: The key move, to prevent the knight's nasty jumps.
moves.5. d4: The good one. Normally, lower rated players go Nf3, that is not bad. But the played one has poison in it.
moves.5... Qa5: Yes, now, it's a loss of tempo. But white cannot do much, despite the aggressive playing he can display. This is the "bet" of this line.
moves.6. Nf3:
From now on, white has the fantastic d5! that opens my game and is often lethal for black. 
But, for some reason, almost nobody plays it!
moves.6... Bf5: I cannot defend against d5 with e3 because I trap my own bishop. After this, black is cramped. It is to be seen if black can consider it a "lock" and hold the game with it.
moves.7. O-O: Second and last lost chance to play d5.
moves.7... e6: Now d5 holds, but white has a ready-made attack with Re1. I still bet black can handle that.
moves.8. Bf4: Ok, good, this is the poisonous diagonal. White has the advantage here, I admit it.
moves.8... Bb4: The normal one is Nf6, with a known game. I tried something new.
moves.9. Bxb8: ? the bishop is much, much more valuable than the knight. Probably, white wanted to prevent a short-to-come o-o-o, that is somewhat double-edged, but is still my favourite, since it places the rook on the best spot connecting the rooks.
moves.10. d5: Nice, and at last played. If cxd, Bb5+!, and if exd, Re1 becomes dangerous. So I tried to mix things up.
moves.10... Bxc3: The main reason for this is that the knight covered the bishop's check in b5.
moves.11. dxe6 Bxe6 12. bxc3: The pawn is less important than the initiative. I have to shield my king, and quickly!
moves.12... Rd8: ...but this move only helps him in defending c3 with tempo. A mistake.
moves.13. Qe1 Nf6 14. Bc4 Nd5: Just in time. All of a sudden, the game becomes tactical!
moves.15. Nd4: So it is seems than the f pawn will be taken on e6 sooner or later. I looked for the circumstance it would have been less dangerous for black.
moves.15... Qxc3: Anything but a queen on the central columns.
moves.16. Qxc3 Nxc3 17. Nxe6 fxe6 18. Bxe6: The less dangerous position for black is reached. I am pretty sure Rd7 is black's best move, but I was staring at an elegant knight replacement.
moves.18... Ne2+ 19. Kh1 Nf4: I'm not sure the knight is better here than in c3, but his king is in a tunnel, and this can be important if endgame is reached.
moves.20. Rfe1 Nxe6 21. Rxe6+ Kf7: Again, the less dangerous position for black. I'm not playing to win, but to hold would be a kind of victory for me.
moves.22. Rae1 Rhe8: The line after Rd2 instead of this is bad for black. Both white rooks penetrate, even if white must lose a tempo in order to free his king. No time to calculate, so I went for drawn.
moves.23. Re6xe8 Rxe8 24. Rxe8 Kxe8: Now, THIS is an endgame. And black has not the worst part of it!
moves.25. f4 Ke7 26. g4 Ke6 27. Kg2 Kd5 28. Kf: I know my king cannot reach the c2 pawn, even if offered (c3, Kd5), because currently I "lose the race" if the king is too far.
moves.29. f5: ? This is not the right path, I fear... c3 was needed. Or h4.
moves.29... Ke5: Thanks, white, you gave me the best place for my king.
moves.30. h4 b5: My turn to go on. White is blocked on the queenside!
moves.31. a3 a5 32. c3 c5 33. Ke3 b4 34. cxb4: ...and white must resign, since while stopping the b pawn, I can take all his pawns. It is very rare for me to get such a "technical" victory, with no sacrifices or big mistakes. This makes me a little proud of this game. :-)
